explanation:
To check the MISRA rule “A function parameter should not be modified” for OS_TaskExit you must be able to determine whether OS_TaskExit itself changes any of its own parameters or accidentally changes pointer parameters via indirect operations. The following symbols are needed and why:

- osal_id_t (typedef): Determines whether task_id is a scalar or a pointer type. If it were a pointer type, assignments or passing it by address could imply pointer modification concerns.

- OS_object_token_t (typedef): Needed to know whether token is a plain struct, a pointer type, or a typedef-to-pointer. That affects interpretation of &token and whether subsequent calls might change pointer values versus pointed-to objects.

- OS_TaskGetId_Impl (prototype): Shows the return type and any side-effects visible in its declaration (e.g., if it is a macro or inline that manipulates caller-scope objects). Required to rule out hidden parameter modifications coming from this call.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById (prototype): Critical because OS_TaskExit passes &token to it. The prototype reveals whether the corresponding parameter is a pointer-to-pointer or pointer-to-object and whether the function may modify the pointer value itself (which matters for MISRA pointer-parameter rules when applied to functions that receive pointers from the caller).

- OS_TaskDetach_Impl (prototype): OS_TaskExit passes &token to this routine. The prototype shows whether the parameter is a pointer that might be modified (pointer value changed) or a pointer-to-object (object modified), and also whether it is a macro/inline that could alter caller parameters.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete (prototype): Same reason as above — &token is passed; need the declaration to know whether the pointer parameter itself could be modified versus the pointed-to object.

- OS_TaskExit_Impl (prototype): Although it never returns, its declaration (or macro definition) must be checked to ensure it is not a macro that expands into code that would modify parameters of OS_TaskExit (if any) or otherwise change caller-scope values in unexpected ways.

- OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_SUCCESS (macros/constants): Provide the semantic context of the conditional and calls. While they are not parameter types, knowing these constants ensures the branch and call-site behavior is interpreted correctly (e.g., whether the conditional is always true/false due to macros, or whether OS_ObjectIdGetById maps to a different implementation via macros).

Collecting the above typedefs and prototypes (and any macro definitions) lets the analyzer determine precisely which values are local variables versus parameters, whether any pointer parameters are being modified (pointer value vs pointed-to object), and whether any called routine is a macro/inline that could implicitly modify parameters of OS_TaskExit.
